title: In Hong Kong, publisher ruffles feathers at a cost
title_page: In Hong Kong, publisher ruffles feathers at a cost - The New York Times
maintext:
HONG KONG â€” Two images greet the visitor to Next Media, the contrarian newspaper and magazine publisher that, here and in Taiwan, is turning political nonconformity into the core of a dynamically successful business model.
One picture is a figure in the lotus position looking out at black clouds and a tide of wild waves. It is a contemporary take on a classical Chinese theme. "Man facing the forces," an employee explained to a visitor.
The other is taped casually to a wall down the corridor: a placard that Next printed for and donated to one of the demonstrations staged by democracy advocates in central Hong Kong. "We don't launch movements," the employee explained, "but we know our audience, and when they're marching, they're going to want to carry something."
It would be hard to conjure up two images that so succinctly describe the turf claimed by Jimmy Lai, Next Media's iconoclastic founder, and Apple Daily, the Chinese-language flagship he founded in 1995: Cover meaningful issues, even if provocative, and put readers before anybody else.
